In mathematics, '''Watson's lemma''', proved by [[G. N. Watson]] (1918, p. 133), has significant application within the theory on the [[asymptotic behavior]] of [[integral]]s.
== Statement of the lemma ==
Let <math>0 < T \leq \infty</math> be fixed. Assume <math>\varphi(t)=t^\lambda\,g(t)</math>, where <math>g(t)</math> has an infinite number of derivatives in the neighborhood of <math>t=0</math>, with <math>g(0)\neq 0</math>, and <math>\lambda > -1</math>.
Suppose, in addition, either that
:<math>|\varphi(t)| < Ke^{bt} \ \forall t>0,</math>
where <math>K,b</math> are independent of <math>t</math>, or that
:<math>\int_0^T |\varphi(t)|\, \mathrm dt < \infty.</math>
Then, it is true that for all positive <math>x</math> that
:<math>\left|\int_0^T e^{-x t}\varphi(t)\, \mathrm dt\right| < \infty</math>
and that the following [[asymptotic equivalence]] holds: :<math>\int_0^T e^{-x t}\varphi(t)\, \mathrm dt \sim\ \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{g^{(n)}(0)\ \Gamma(\lambda+n+1)}{n!\ x^{\lambda+n+1}},\ \ (x>0,\ x\rightarrow \infty).</math>
See, for instance, {{harvtxt|Watson|1918}} for the original proof or {{harvtxt|Miller|2006}} for a more recent development.
== Proof ==
We will prove the version of Watson's lemma which assumes that <math>|\varphi(t)|</math> has at most exponential growth as <math>t \to \infty</math>. The basic idea behind the proof is that we will approximate <math>g(t)</math> by finitely many terms of its Taylor series. Since the derivatives of <math>g</math> are only assumed to exist in a neighborhood of the origin, we will essentially proceed by removing the tail of the integral, applying [[Taylor's theorem#Explicit formulae for the remainder|Taylor's theorem with remainder]] in the remaining small interval, then adding the tail back on in the end. At each step we will carefully estimate how much we are throwing away or adding on. This proof is a modification of the one found in {{harvtxt|Miller|2006}}.
Let <math>0 < T \leq \infty</math> and suppose that <math>\varphi</math> is a measurable function of the form <math>\varphi(t) = t^\lambda g(t)</math>, where <math>\lambda > -1</math> and <math>g</math> has an infinite number of continuous derivatives in the interval <math>[0,\delta]</math> for some <math>0 < \delta < T</math>, and that <math>|\varphi(t)| \leq Ke^{bt}</math> for all <math>\delta \leq t \leq T</math>, where the constants <math>K</math> and <math>b</math> are independent of <math>t</math>.
We can show that the integral is finite for <math>x</math> large enough by writing :<math>(1) \quad \int_0^T e^{-xt}\varphi(t)\,\mathrm dt = \int_0^\delta e^{-xt} \varphi(t)\,\mathrm dt + \int_\delta^T e^{-xt}\varphi(t)\,\mathrm dt</math> and estimating each term.
For the first term we have :<math>\left|\int_0^\delta e^{-xt}\varphi(t)\,\mathrm dt\right| \leq \int_0^\delta e^{-xt}|\varphi(t)|\,\mathrm dt \leq \int_0^\delta |\varphi(t)|\,\mathrm dt</math> for <math>x \geq 0</math>, where the last integral is finite by the assumptions that <math>g</math> is continuous on the interval <math>[0,\delta]</math> and that <math>\lambda > -1</math>. For the second term we use the assumption that <math>\varphi</math> is exponentially bounded to see that, for <math>x > b</math>, :<math>\begin{align} \left|\int_\delta^T e^{-xt}\varphi(t)\,\mathrm dt\right| &\leq \int_\delta^T e^{-xt} |\varphi(t)|\,\mathrm dt \\ &\leq K \int_\delta^T e^{(b-x)t}\,\mathrm dt \\ &\leq K \int_\delta^\infty e^{(b-x)t}\,\mathrm dt \\ &= K \, \frac{e^{(b-x)\delta}}{x-b}. \end{align}</math> The finiteness of the original integral then follows from applying the triangle inequality to <math>(1)</math>.
We can deduce from the above calculation that :<math>(2) \quad \int_0^T e^{-xt}\varphi(t)\,\mathrm dt = \int_0^\delta e^{-xt} \varphi(t)\,\mathrm dt + O\left(x^{-1} e^{-\delta x}\right)</math> as <math>x \to \infty</math>.
By appealing to [[Taylor's theorem#Explicit formulae for the remainder|Taylor's theorem with remainder]] we know that, for each integer <math>N \geq 0</math>, :<math>g(t) = \sum_{n=0}^{N} \frac{g^{(n)}(0)}{n!}\,t^n + \frac{g^{(N+1)}(t^*)}{(N+1)!}\,t^{N+1}</math> for <math>0 \leq t \leq \delta</math>, where <math>0 \leq t^* \leq t</math>. Plugging this in to the first term in <math>(2)</math> we get :<math>\begin{align} (3) \quad \int_0^\delta e^{-xt} \varphi(t)\,\mathrm dt &= \int_0^\delta e^{-xt} t^\lambda g(t)\,\mathrm dt \\ &= \sum_{n=0}^{N} \frac{g^{(n)}(0)}{n!} \int_0^\delta t^{\lambda + n} e^{-xt}\,\mathrm dt + \frac{1}{(N+1)!} \int_0^\delta g^{(N+1)}(t^*)\, t^{\lambda+N+1} e^{-xt}\,\mathrm dt. \end{align}</math> To bound the term involving the remainder we use the assumption that <math>g^{(N+1)}</math> is continuous on the interval <math>[0,\delta]</math>, and in particular it is bounded there. As such we see that :<math>\begin{align} \left|\int_0^\delta g^{(N+1)}(t^*)\, t^{\lambda+N+1} e^{-xt}\,\mathrm dt\right| &\leq \sup_{t \in [0,\delta]} \left|g^{(N+1)}(t)\right| \int_0^\delta t^{\lambda+N+1} e^{-xt}\,\mathrm dt \\ &< \sup_{t \in [0,\delta]} \left|g^{(N+1)}(t)\right| \int_0^\infty t^{\lambda+N+1} e^{-xt}\,\mathrm dt \\ &= \sup_{t \in [0,\delta]} \left|g^{(N+1)}(t)\right| \,\frac{\Gamma(\lambda + N + 2)}{x^{\lambda+N+2}}. \end{align}</math> Here we have used the fact that :<math>\int_0^\infty t^a e^{-xt}\,\mathrm dt = \frac{\Gamma(a+1)}{x^{a+1}}</math> if <math>x > 0</math> and <math>a > -1</math>, where <math>\Gamma</math> is the [[gamma function]].
From the above calculation we see from <math>(3)</math> that :<math>(4) \quad \int_0^\delta e^{-xt} \varphi(t)\,\mathrm dt = \sum_{n=0}^N \frac{g^{(n)}(0)}{n!} \int_0^\delta t^{\lambda + n} e^{-xt}\,\mathrm dt + O\left(x^{-\lambda-N-2}\right)</math> as <math>x \to \infty</math>.
We will now add the tails on to each integral in <math>(4)</math>. For each <math>n</math> we have :<math>\begin{align} \int_0^\delta t^{\lambda + n} e^{-xt}\,\mathrm dt &= \int_0^\infty t^{\lambda + n} e^{-xt}\,\mathrm dt - \int_\delta^\infty t^{\lambda + n} e^{-xt}\,\mathrm dt \\[5pt] &= \frac{\Gamma(\lambda+n+1)}{x^{\lambda+n+1}} - \int_\delta^\infty t^{\lambda + n} e^{-xt}\,\mathrm dt, \end{align}</math> and we will show that the remaining integrals are exponentially small. Indeed, if we make the change of variables <math>t = s + \delta</math> we get :<math>\begin{align} \int_\delta^\infty t^{\lambda + n} e^{-xt}\,\mathrm dt &= \int_0^\infty (s+\delta)^{\lambda + n} e^{-x(s+\delta)}\,ds \\[5pt] &= e^{-\delta x} \int_0^\infty (s+\delta)^{\lambda + n} e^{-xs}\,ds \\[5pt] &\leq e^{-\delta x} \int_0^\infty (s+\delta)^{\lambda + n} e^{-s}\,ds \end{align}</math> for <math>x \geq 1</math>, so that :<math>\int_0^\delta t^{\lambda + n} e^{-xt}\,\mathrm dt = \frac{\Gamma(\lambda+n+1)}{x^{\lambda+n+1}} + O\left(e^{-\delta x}\right) \text{ as } x \to \infty.</math>
If we substitute this last result into <math>(4)</math> we find that :<math>\begin{align} \int_0^\delta e^{-xt} \varphi(t)\,\mathrm dt &= \sum_{n=0}^{N} \frac{g^{(n)}(0) \ \Gamma(\lambda+n+1)}{n! \ x^{\lambda+n+1}} + O\left(e^{-\delta x}\right) + O\left(x^{-\lambda-N-2}\right) \\ &= \sum_{n=0}^{N} \frac{g^{(n)}(0) \ \Gamma(\lambda+n+1)}{n! \ x^{\lambda+n+1}} + O\left(x^{-\lambda-N-2}\right) \end{align}</math> as <math>x \to \infty</math>. Finally, substituting this into <math>(2)</math> we conclude that :<math>\begin{align} \int_0^T e^{-xt}\varphi(t)\,\mathrm dt &= \sum_{n=0}^{N} \frac{g^{(n)}(0) \ \Gamma(\lambda+n+1)}{n! \ x^{\lambda+n+1}} + O\left(x^{-\lambda-N-2}\right) + O\left(x^{-1} e^{-\delta x}\right) \\ &= \sum_{n=0}^{N} \frac{g^{(n)}(0) \ \Gamma(\lambda+n+1)}{n! \ x^{\lambda+n+1}} + O\left(x^{-\lambda-N-2}\right) \end{align}</math> as <math>x \to \infty</math>.
Since this last expression is true for each integer <math>N \geq 0</math> we have thus shown that :<math>\int_0^T e^{-xt}\varphi(t)\,\mathrm dt \sim \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{g^{(n)}(0) \ \Gamma(\lambda+n+1)}{n! \ x^{\lambda+n+1}}</math> as <math>x \to \infty</math>, where the infinite series is interpreted as an [[asymptotic expansion]] of the integral in question.
== Example == When <math>0 < a < b</math>, the [[confluent hypergeometric function]] of the first kind has the integral representation :<math>{}_1F_1(a,b,x) = \frac{\Gamma(b)}{\Gamma(a) \Gamma(b-a)}\int_0^1 e^{xt} t^{a-1} (1-t)^{b-a-1}\,\mathrm dt,</math> where <math>\Gamma</math> is the [[gamma function]]. The change of variables <math>t = 1-s</math> puts this into the form :<math>{}_1F_1(a,b,x) = \frac{\Gamma(b)}{\Gamma(a) \Gamma(b-a)}\,e^x\int_0^1 e^{-xs} (1-s)^{a-1} s^{b-a-1}\,ds,</math> which is now amenable to the use of Watson's lemma. Taking <math>\lambda = b-a-1</math> and <math>g(s) = (1-s)^{a-1}</math>, Watson's lemma tells us that :<math>\int_0^1 e^{-xs} (1-s)^{a-1} s^{b-a-1}\,ds \sim \Gamma(b-a) x^{a-b} \quad \text{as } x \to \infty \text{ with } x > 0,</math> which allows us to conclude that :<math> {}_1F_1(a,b,x) \sim \frac{\Gamma(b)}{\Gamma(a)}\,x^{a-b} e^x \quad \text{as } x \to \infty \text{ with } x > 0.</math>
